text:
```WARNING: using CairoMakie.AbstractPlotting in module Main conflicts with an existing identifier.```
wut

elements.text: WARNING: using CairoMakie.AbstractPlotting in module Main conflicts with an existing identifier.

text: I'm not 100% about that one, but Cairo Maki reexports all of Abstractplotting, so that it's enough to just use the Backend and no other package

elements.text: I'm not 100% about that one, but Cairo Maki reexports all of Abstractplotting, so that it's enough to just use the Backend and no other package

text: Weird though, I thought typically if you have modules A and B and B does `@reexport using A`, `using A, B` will be fine because `A === B.A`. Guess I'm wrong on that? Or maybe that changed at some point?

elements.text: Weird though, I thought typically if you have modules A and B and B does
. Guess I'm wrong on that? Or maybe that changed at some point?

text: That's why I'm not sure what's going on^^

text:
Aha! I figured it out! It's the hard vs. soft binding distinction.
```julia> module A
       f() = 1
       export f
       end
Main.A

julia> module B
       import ..A: A, f
       export A, f
       end
Main.B

julia> using .A, .B
WARNING: using B.A in module Main conflicts with an existing identifier.```
Compare that to
```julia> module A
       f() = 1
       export f
       end
Main.A

julia> module B
       using ..A: A, f
       export A, f
       end
Main.B

julia> using .A, .B```

elements.text: Aha! I figured it out! It's the hard vs. soft binding distinction.

julia> module A
       f() = 1
       export f
       end
Main.A

julia> module B
       import ..A: A, f
       export A, f
       end
Main.B

julia> using .A, .B
WARNING: using B.A in module Main conflicts with an existing identifier.

julia> module A
       f() = 1
       export f
       end
Main.A

julia> module B
       using ..A: A, f
       export A, f
       end
Main.B

julia> using .A, .B

text: It's because the reexporting being used is implemented using `import` rather than `using`

elements.text: It's because the reexporting being used is implemented using
